Now, to the second part of the question you are seeing in emerging markets unless they are a oil producing type of environment, et cetera, their budgets both of government and their core businesses got squeezed much tougher than many of the developed countries world's did, and so their ability to respond back becomes more a challenging on it, but I am pretty comfortable with where we are in emerging.

The markets that I'm actually concerned about that are going to probably lag by a couple of quarters the rest of the world are in Europe. and again, that's not an execution on our team's part, I've got a great team over there and Rob has a great team. I just think they were couple of quarters later going into this and you are seeing some pretty severe challenges in the U.K, Spain, and Italy. You have countries like Germany, that I think are managing through and are doing pretty well, but in total Western Europe and Eastern Europe I think are our challenge.

In terms of the margin analysis, it's a mix issue as much as anything, and to me trending down or not. I would think 63, 64, and we clearly gave a margin indication for this next quarter, at the higher end of that. Now, we will have different mix issues which contribute to that, but I think these are pretty solid margins given the new markets we're moving into, the volume we're into et cetera.
Frank?

John, let me just add two things, one on the product side on the gross margin, as I mentioned we now have some recent organizations – acquisitions that we brought into the business, which will have a negative impact on the mix, as well as some of the new products especially in some of the adjacent markets that we talked about, as they are early in their lifecycle, as well as the margin structure on those are lower. That plays into the mix on the product side.

And then the other thing quickly I wanted to say on the service side is that as we have been mentioning now for a couple of quarters, we're investing heavily in Advanced Services primarily in support of data centers. We started bringing on additional head count in the Q3-Q4 timeframe that are going to be impacting the costs in Q1 that will bring the margins down on service side primarily because of the additional costs but it's also going to change the mix between our technical services and our Advanced services which do tend to have lower margins. So those are the dynamics that we're taking into consideration in the guidance that we provided for Q1.

Yeah, and the one question I didn't get, Blair – and Ittai, thank you very much – is where we're going with cloud, some of these new architectures and how our strategy in cloud really pulls in many of the other strategies in many areas. Padma, maybe if you could give us a snapshot on that since you're leading the strategy for me on cloud and the implementation and a little bit how it might tie to some of the other things we're doing.

Sure, thank you, John. Cloud is – we believe is perhaps one of the most network-centric architectural shifts that we're going see in the IT industry in a long time. And the reason we believe that to be the case is virtualization is going to be the foundation to drive that, and so UCS becomes a core element from an architecture perspective in how we can enable large enterprises to build their own private clouds, as well as service providers to provide the capability of virtual private clouds to enterprises and small businesses.

Our cloud strategy is to link from an infrastructure perspective what we're doing in the data center all the way to the application delivery through SaaS, with the SaaS offerings that we currently have with WebEx conferencing, security as a service with IronPort, and some of the other capabilities. The key differentiation that we are focused on with respect to the network enablement is in providing security, which is a key concern of most enterprises in today architecture with Cloud, as well as enabling higher levels of service agreements and providing the interoperability between different Cloud architectures.
So, an area to kind of stay tuned on and Blair let me give it back to you. You ran this exactly on time and you didn't have to nudge me except once or twice, so let's keep the pace going.

No, kicking this quarter. Great, thanks, John and everyone. Cisco's next quarterly conference call, which will reflect our first quarter fiscal 2010 results will be on Wednesday, November 4, 2009 at 1:30 PM Pacific, 4:30 PM Eastern. And additionally, as I said, before, downloadable Q4 and FY 2009 financial statements will be available following this call, including revenue segments by product and geography, income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information, balance sheets and cash flow statements can be found on our website in the Investor Relations section. Just click on the financials section of the website.

Again, I would like to remind you that in light of Regulation Fair Disclosure, Cisco plans to retain its long-standing policy not to comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure. Please feel free to call the Investor Relations department with any follow-up questions from the call. Thank you for your participation and continued support and this concludes our call.

Thank you for participating on today's conference call. If you would like to listen to the call in its entirety, you may call 866-357-4205. For participants dialing from outside the U.S., please dial 203-369-0122.
